Jeff,

Your last post was how I wanted to respond to Petar, but your
explan=
ation is much better.  From reading the published papers, I
can't find a pe=
nalty for using HyperNEAT even if NEAT by itself may
suffice.  Am I correct=
 here?

--Todd

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote:=

>
> There are other benefits to HyperNEAT that have nothing to do with
geo=
metry,
> no? It is an indirect encoding, and thus is more likely to create
=
modular
> phenotypes that exhibit repetitions and symmetry (with and withou=
t
> variation).
> 
> Unless I am mistaken, these benefits can cause HyperNE=
AT to
outperform NEAT
> even on problems where geometry is not being exploi=
ted. Does that sound
> right to everyone?
> 
> 
> Cheers,
> Jeff Clune
>

 Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University
